instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3436: What is 820-3436? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
Make that an [B]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B[/B] rather.
(I haven't even started drinking at my desk yet... :/ )


History is a bit unclear, but was definitely water damaged.

Replaced the DC board with a spare one. Now it gets a green light for a split second and then it goes out and the fans turn on full. It doesn't speed up, it just goes full speed.

Not getting <SIGNAL>P3PVS0_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message: Nothing to go on and <SIGNAL>P3PVS0_EN</SIGNAL> does not exist.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
I'm taking measurements! Have them up in a moment.

And that was a typo; <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
[SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
I am trying to find where <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> is not coming from.

<DIODE>D8184</DIODE>::1 = 16mV
<DIODE>D8184</DIODE>::2 = 16mV

<RESISTOR>R8184</RESISTOR> = 16mV.

Pin 4 of <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> is 0v so nothing after that is going to give me anything....

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> comes from the same place as <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R8186</RESISTOR>/87). So check the traces and resistors in <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> lines.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
What should I expect to see from <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>::Pin 4 (<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>) ?

I'm getting 16.5mV, which makes wonder how it can ever be turned into <SIGNAL>5V_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_EN</SIGNAL>, I can't see another power line involved anywhere.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
In post #4 you say you have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, this suggests <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> is there, check again.
Also if pin 1,2 and 5 of <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> have voltage then pin 4 should be high too, check again.
Actually if the fan spins usually all power is ok with possibly the exception of CPU Vcore. Check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Also I'm looking at the 3435 diagram as <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> does not exist.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
(The board is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, I corrected myself in the first post.)


There is no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> at this stage.

Pin 4 is definitely low on <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>, and pins 1,2 & 5 are definitely at 3.345v.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0;

What would cause the green light to go out after a little time?
Sometimes it's green for a few seconds, sometimes a split second. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present everywhere i check.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
But I do have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET_R</SIGNAL>....

Is that even possible?


Edit.

At <CAPACITOR>C8080</CAPACITOR>, but nothing at <RESISTOR>R8187</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is back @ <CAPACITOR>C7320</CAPACITOR>

The bloody thing must be intermittent. :/


Edit:
Gone in the bin.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3436</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light for half a second, then full fan.
threads.message:
Had some time so took a second look; a pin on the flex cable from the DCBoard to the MLB was burnt out.
Groan.

Swapped that over and it behaves as expected.

Learnt to be more thorough with this one. I tried known good DC Boards but used the same flex cable each time....

Mark this as solved/closed please.
